job_title: Assistant School Education Service Manager in Leeds, England
pros: Really good holiday allowance and flexible working opportunities (hybrid)
cons: Teams are under resourced and workloads are high, the holiday allowance is great but in reality I find that all of my time off is used to "recover" from work. Little to no support for managers when dealing with complex issues. There are high expectations from students and academic colleagues which realistically there isn't the resource to provide, as a middle manager you are in the firing line about this on a daily basis. There is a lot of inconsistency between roles, you could be a manager of a 10 person team, with twice the workload of a person managing a 3 person team but you get paid the same. Staff turnover is high and there are constantly gaps in teams, there is no contingency plan for resource gaps which creates bad feeling within teams and falls back on to you as a middle manager. The systems are very outdated and a lot of data entry work is done manually, this creates a lot of pressure especially at busy times in the academic calendar. There also isn't the understanding from academic colleagues of how bad the systems are, so they may ask for a "simple report" when in reality it would take days to pull together the data they are asking for from various different systems.

review_title: Great people on the whole but senior management decisions make me feel like crying

pros: The University of Leeds is a world-leading university for research. The union and student services are fantastic. Although the mental health services could do with being bigger and better funded (as they all do) the level of service from the counsellors is excellent. There is also active encouragement on a university and department level to identify what training would benefit you and depending on your funding source there's is an expectation to spend some of your assigned funding on external training as well as internal.
cons:
Experience doing a PhD will vary hugely depending on your research group and supervisors. For me I felt lacking support at times and ultimately left the position after 3 years as a result. I find some professors are significantly lacking in interpersonal skills and as such I felt unable to talk with them about some more personal sides to my PhD such as my mental health. 

The way the mental health services are set up meant at the time I was most struggling I was given a small number of sessions (with the possibility of entending if the counsellor felt it was necessary). After that you could refer again for more help. You definitely got the impression that counsellors were strectched thin and could only achieve so much with the resources they have. I felt a bit like putting a plaster over the problem each time and I had to go elsewhere for a more in-depth, lengthier treatment plan.

review_title: Brilliant place to work, excellent facilities & staff benefits. Certainly one of the best employers in the country.
pros: The working culture is very employee focused, with flexible working patterns being available. Great support available for staff and the facilities (such as the gym) are superb. Excellent holidays and the variety of work means no two days are the same. You meet a broad spectrum of people, from all walks of life and working on Campus is a breath of fresh air. Been at Leeds for five years and enjoyed every day.
cons:
Staff can become jaded or institutionalised if they've been working in the same job for too long so not everyone is as enthusiastic as myself. Neither are all the jobs as interesting as my own so I wouldn't say my views reflect everyone's.

The workload can be excessive on occasion, but there aren't many jobs where this isn't true.

review_title: The Strategy is "Increasing knowledge and opportunity" BUT the reality is admin gets in the way
pros: Great if you like using lots of different admin IT systems, and/or like lots of admin, rather than teaching and research!
cons: Academic staff have LOTS of online paperwork. Every Intranet admin function uses a different IT system withn a different interface: undergrad teaching admin has VLE, Student turoring has "Leeds for Life", Research Postgrad admin has PDR, Research project management has KRISTAL and incomprehensible Excel spreadsheets, Research proposal admin has J-eS, Research publications has Symplectic, HR has a weird "psychadelic trip" website I cannot fathom, ... I keep asking for plain text which I can use without mouse and complex navigation, but everyone just passes the buck and says it's IT...

pros:
What I really love about working at the University of Leeds is that I am free to pursue my own interests within the framework of our strategy. So long as what I do fulfils the objectives, I am able to carve out my own route, which means I am always enthusiastic and motivated about what I am doing. 
I also like the opportunity to interact with people outside of my own Faculty across the whole organisation, and have the pleasure of working with some truly amazing and inspiring people. 
There are also great opportunities for personal development and a very positive and inclusive culture.
cons: The only drawback is that I can be a victim of my own enthusiasm and that no-one will ever tell you not to do things. You need to be able to balance your own workload and priorities effectively here.

review_title: This is a large institutions with many good innovations (but it does think a lot of itself)
job_title: Academic Skills Development Tutor in Leeds, England
pros: The campus is great - with some brilliant facilities and there are quite a lot of options for personal development. There are some good staff benefits, and, within the Lifelong Learning Centre, a great and lovely range of students.
cons: The bureaucracy can be a bit unwieldy, and all the innovations mean there is always a struggle for space. Money is spent on buildings and promotional material - It would be good if there was more of a balance so it was also spent on staff to support the students (I really don't understand the cutbacks to library staff).

pros: For many people the university is typical of many stable academic institutions and will offer its non-academic staff a pleasant working environment, ample holidays and plenty of interesting activities when off-the-clock. All in all, the university treats its staff reasonably and most people seem happy.
cons: Remuneration is definitely on the low side compared to working in the private sector, but this is typical of most universities. Only found out I had been 'opted out' of the pension a good while after the fact, without ever having been consulted. I was furious about this. Sometimes it can be tricky to get things to happen, especially with IT. Persistence and knowing where someone's office is can help when it gets too much!

pros:
Flexible working and employer recognises importance of work/life balance
Fair salary and benefits i.e. good pension / mat leave & sick pay above statutory
Good holiday entitlement
Relatively easy to progress (if you work hard and your face fits!)
cons:
Responsibility and grading are not in line across the University - many staff are paid the same with a huge difference in the work they do and expectations of them
Constant restructures/realignments which cause a unsettling atmosphere amongst staff
Challenging academic - support staff relationships in some areas
Bullying and inappropriate/unprofessional behaviour by a minority of senior staff and academics is not addressed
Very difficult to implement more efficient policies and processes in such a big organisation

review_title: If you like to get things done, this is not the place for you
pros: Very flexible re. work balance.  Lectures are not really expected to be there at their offices other than when teaching.  If they can find some conference or research project, then they can actually live hundreds of miles away and show up once a month.
cons: Clogged by paperwork.  This is not an innovative or creative place.  This is a bureaucracy.  Everything done in here is about making sure the Uni is not sued.  Staff are afraid of students and students show little interest in staff.  Research is about publications, not about knowledge.

pros:
Of course with PhD courses the experience varies wildly by the lab you are in, so I will speak about my dealings with the department and central Uni.
At first I found it difficult to get a hold of a student card, as the information when you first join is a bit sparse, and it took until a few weeks after I started work to get a contract drawn up, which was awkward.
The support services for postgraduates are fantastic. Everyone in the admin section of my department is really helpful, and services such as physical and mental health help is clearly marked out, with efficient and caring services, particularly when there are no undergraduates about.
cons:
Some housing in the area is not so great. 
Dealings with central admin can be lengthy.

review_title: Lovely environment (worked at Weetwood sports facilities). Great work colleagues let down by senior management.
pros: Excellent facilities, constantly being developed and improved.
cons: If you like hockey, even better play or coach the sport you will be in demand and progress in work here. However don't expect a clear and transparent job pathway, Hockey players appear to be head hunted and given jobs. The facilities manager (although competent and efficient)  seems to use his budget as a recruitment tool, to progress his own hobby.

review_title: Leeds by name but not by nature!
pros: Mostly very good people. It's a well known institution and is mid-ranking in the UK. The University has a lot of potential, but it needs to up its game.
cons: The University does not know where it is going. Far too much concentration on strategy with no thought paid to delivery. Senior managers are very ego driven and do not think about consequences of their actions on the staff. Very difficult to get a decision made. Far too much paperwork making all internal processes very slow.

pros: Flexibility of working hours, terms and conditions.  Friendly people.  So much is given to staff that you are happy to give more back when it is needed without grumbling, like putting in extra hours.
cons: Red tape, bureacracy and paperwork (real or virtual) can sometimes be a barrier to completing tasks or in most cases draws out the time it takes.  The academic/management 'hierarchy' can make it confusing who you need to get to make a decision on something.  Too many and too frequent reviews and restructures of schools and institutes which result in extended periods of no progress due to financial freezing.

pros:
Held the role whilst studying at the University. 

Genuinely great people to work with and institution to work for. they place a huge emphasis on staff development (courses,workshops, funding etc) and you have a genuine sense of job security whilst working for them. Plus the wage, hourly in my case, was way beyond a comparative role in a commercial company.
cons: Way to much in the way of bureaucracy and pandering to particular elements (Student Union etc). Also, way too open to cronyism in regards to lower-mid level management and their cliques.

review_title: Generally, a lovely environment in which to work, if a bit a bureaucratic behemoth!
pros: Some of the campus is very attractive, although spoiled somewhat by hideous 1970's concrete buildings.  The pay is good, and the work varied.  As an employee you cross paths with lots of interesting people, and opportunities for networking are good, if you take them!
cons: Many curriculum approval processes are very bureaucratic and lengthy, and so the institution struggles to keep up with the speed of change in the modern age, particularly when compared to smaller competitors.  Changes of policy are not always fully consulted on, or well-communicated.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Leeds, England
pros: Great company pension contribution and work is limited to EU time constraints (although, personally I favour project management which gets the job done and not partially done within the time constraints).
cons: Bosses are pushed towards publications meaning work can be highly pressured (but that is how I work best) and performance is rated on attainment and not attempts, so to be successful one has to not only work hard but work accurately.

pros: Secure employment, good pension scheme. It's a good place to work if you're not looking to move up the ladder quickly.
cons: Hard to progress, the free courses on offer will not help you get a better job. Lots of issues starting to bubble up (in union meetings). Long hours, no overtime payments, lack of support from management. Issues with difficult colleagues not dealt with at all, leading to toxic work environments.

review_title: My experience of working at the University of Leeds has been generally good with opportunity for progression
pros: Fantastic working environment with a focus on promoting interdisciplinary collaboration. There is good support from staff at higher levels and opportunities for development through workshops. Flexible hours and holiday are also a bonus
cons: Some of the support from information technology and purchasing finance is not up to scratch. These departments can actually be obstructive at times. Leadership positions need to be more carefully considered

review_title: An excellent company to wokr for.
pros: Good rates of pay,, great holiday entitlement, some good employee benefits. Excellent training options with an extensive course programme for staff.
cons:
Many people take advantage of the company's leniency with regard to sick pay and call in sick a lot. Lots of staff end up on long term sick leave when there is nothing wrong with them which puts undue pressure on other members of the teams.
The employee benefis package isnt as good as it could be, for instance the gym membership is still too expensive for many people, even with the staff discount.

pros: Supervisors and scientists at the University are typically excellent. I've felt very well supported in my current department and have made many lifelong friends. Funding to the University is good and the facilities are very good.
cons: The University can sometimes be overly bureaucratic - finance departments can sometimes be poor and things like student registration are a pain. Admin departments can sometimes be poor. I feel like this can sometimes take away from the excellent work being done at Leeds. Pressure for publications is also a problem but this is a system wide problem over all Universities.

pros: A good amount of flexibility of hours and working practices can be found. It varies from department to department, however there is a definite emphasis on trying to get work life balance right, if not always communicated that well.
cons:
Slow to make decisions, just because you are an academic doesn't make you a good manager or good at setting strategy for running a large organisation.

Did I mention slow??? 

Politics.....and ego's, may be not that different from corporates after all!

pros: University of Leeds provides a good level of support in terms of training (e.g. research, programming etc.).
cons: High demands in terms of publishing combined with a high teaching load. In my first year I was a leader for two modules with a responsibility to teach all lectures and all seminars. Needless to say, I got limited research done. This obviously varies by department, but in many other universities new lecturers have no teaching obligations in their first year.

pros:
1. High quality research profile in chemical engineering
2. Diversity of research fields
3. High quality lab equipment
4. Located in a nice city
5. Friendly and helpful people
cons:
1. Salary is a bit low for high level education degrees compared to industry
2. Currently, chemical engineering building is under refurb hence a lot of distractions
3. recently, the research budgets are decreasing whereas other universities has increased their research budget

pros:
Continuous training and support for students. 
A lot of free courses that make you competitive in the job market and close collaboration with industry.
cons: Laboratories are not fully equipped for the research I was working on. Some very important equipment are almost always fully booked and you at times have to wait as long as 1 month to use certain equipment.

job_title: Clerical Grade III in Leeds, England
pros: An understanding employer, great holidays, pleasant working environment and a reasonable pay scale.
cons: Hard work and commitment isn't always rewarded, some middle managers are weak and ignore laziness.  Too many staff have too many sickness days.  At times the culture can seem like a holiday camp.

review_title: Great place to be a PhD student
pros: Dynamic and lively atmosphere in the School of Geography. Lots of other PhD students which is great for stimulating discussion, coming up with ideas, getting support when things are challenging and a generally good working atmosphere. Lots of high quality research going on.
cons: Can only speak for my department, but fairly hierarchical between academics and students, would be nice to have more casual interactions with senior staff

pros: Great Atmosphere, supervisors are easy going and easy to talk to. Breaks are nice and you get to meet new people and talk to former students. Aside from this you are raising money which looks good on a CV. It's very flexible and the socials are worth going to.
cons: The shift times can be awkward and sometimes you get cranky people on the phones. But most calls are pleasant and there are always supervisors willing to help you get better on the phones.

pros:
Great pension scheme
Flexible hours
lots of on the job training, lots of course being carried out through the learning and development service year round
cons: Short term contracts for researchers make planning life very different. Lack of job security makes it a stressful environment to work in.

pros:
The University Job site is great, I got several interviews. 
The senior staff are happy to offer information of jobs upcoming in the department if you are a good worker. 
The redeployment register is also a great resource. 
The people I worked with were fantastic - very welcoming and supportive.
Great pension plan.
cons: I wasn't able to find a permanent position. Maybe it's the job market at the moment but the admin/clerical work was all part-time and/or temporary.

pros: Leeds has a great name, in some cases has great resources, and, therefore, its great to have on your CV.
cons: Management of post-doctoral/early-career researchers at a University level is poor. There is an archaic system for retaining staff on fixed term contracts, for example having to go on to a redeployment register to, in some cases, re-apply for your job. The promotion process is also more hassle than simply joining a different university.

pros: Large wealthy company. Lots of jobs. Supporting students can be rewarding
cons:
Hard work and conscientiousness often not that valued. 
Turning a blind eye to incompetence and indifference becomes a work skill.

pros: Great working environment in multidisciplinary Astbury centre allows for great working collaborations. The university is friendly and welcoming as is the city.
cons: Low salary for a role that involved lots of hard work and for a highly qualified position. Can sometimes feel undervalued because of this reason

job_title: Student Education Projects Assistant in Leeds, England
pros: Colleagues are nice, no office drama. You will be encouraged to take training regularly and there are sufficient training programmes and support available. People do help you develop. Your voice is valued. Good holiday. Great place for school leavers to learn about the office basics.
cons: Working in public sector means sometimes your work life can be a bit slow paced. The real business world is a lot more efficiency seeking and harsher than the university.

review_title: Nice people and culture, shame about management
pros: The people at the university are lovely and the union is really well organised.
cons: The pension strike really jaded me to the institution it became clear that management doesn't care about staff, they just want to look good to students. Jobs are becoming too temporary without enough freedom. Would be much better if academics were back in control.

pros:
The staff are very friendly. 
You are allowed to engage in tutoring undergraduates and invigilating exams. These duties are also very well paid. 
My supervisors encouraged me to participate in tutoring, marking, going to conferences. They recognised the importance of doing other stuff apart from research.
The students are very well behaved and enthusiastic. This made tutoring small and large classes very easy, given my previous lack of experience.
cons: The job doesn't last forever.

review_title: Great place to work for job security, training and work life balance
pros:
They invest in training for employees where they see potential. I have undertaken an HR degree part funded by the uni and was allowed time off to attend classes.

They look after their staff and jobs are relatively secure.
cons: It can be difficult to get promoted when in a role due to funding restrictions so it is often easier to move roles rather than get promoted.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Leeds, South East England, England
pros: Good city to work.  Great scientific atmosphere in the lab group with lots of development and help for you to reach coals
cons: Pressure to publish is high. Guidance from supervisor was not very useful, you are left on your own  to make decisions without much input.

pros:

pros: Flexible to fit around studies, well organised, good pay higher than minimum wage. The team leaders did a good job of allocating work based on demand and training sessions were useful.
cons: At times it was very cold on the open days and doors had to be kept open in the halls for some reason. Some people were very lazy and should have been told to pick up the slack.
